stages.description: A large flat cream-colored seed with a prominent ridge along one edge.
Thick hypocotyl muscles through the soil, often lifting the seed coat above ground.
Two oversized round cotyledons unfold. First true leaf already hints at palmate shape with rough bristly texture.
Explosive outward growth. Enormous palmate leaves on thick hollow petioles double the plant's footprint weekly, shading everything beneath.
Large golden-orange trumpet flowers open at dawn. Male flowers appear first on long stems; female flowers sit close to the stem with a miniature fruit visible at the base.
Dark green cylindrical fruit swells at an almost absurd rate — check daily or they become baseball-bat-sized marrows. Each fruit hides under the canopy of leaves.
Powdery white patches spread across leaves. Stems become hollow and snap easily. Last fruits are pale and seedy.

companions.lore: Traditional Three Sisters planting. Corn provides vertical structure while squash leaves shade the ground, retaining moisture for both.
The other Three Sisters partner. Beans fix atmospheric nitrogen that feeds the hungry squash plant's aggressive growth.
French marigolds repel squash bugs and cucumber beetles with their pungent root exudates and strong scent.

antagonists.lore: Fennel's allelopathic root exudates inhibit cucurbit growth. A bad neighbor for nearly everything in the garden.
Potatoes and squash compete aggressively for the same soil nutrients and moisture, stunting both. Potatoes may also increase squash susceptibility to blight.

stages.description: White powdery spots appear on upper leaf surfaces, starting with oldest leaves closest to the ground.
Affected leaves yellow as photosynthesis is blocked. White coating spreads to stems and new growth. Fruit production drops.
Leaves become crispy brown and curl. Severely weakened plant may still produce small, pale fruit.
Sudden wilting of a single vine section in midday heat, recovering by evening. Look for sawdust-like frass at the stem base.
Mushy, hollowed-out stem section where the larva is boring through. Frass accumulates visibly. Affected vine wilts permanently.
Entire plant collapses as the borer severs internal vascular tissue. Stem crumbles when squeezed.
Water-soaked spot appears on the blossom end of developing fruit. Calcium transport disrupted by irregular watering.
Dark, sunken, leathery patch on fruit tip. Fruit is still edible if the rot is cut away, but quality is lost.

lore.description: A vigorous bush zucchini that produces glossy dark green cylindrical fruit at an almost alarming rate — the classic 'leave them on your neighbor's porch' summer squash.
lore.origin: Central America (Mesoamerica); the cultivar name and modern form developed in Italy, where 'zucchini' means 'little squash'
lore.fun_fact: A single zucchini plant can produce 6-10 pounds of fruit per week at peak season. Miss one harvest and you'll find a fruit the size of your forearm hiding under those enormous leaves.
